awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A portable rapid cycling compression device to prevent blood clots
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to reduce the incidence of blood clots in individuals outside a clinical care setting. Venous blood clots are a common event in individuals who recently been discharged from a hospital or clinical care setting, with an estimated 500,000 cases annually in the US alone. Venous clots cause leg pain and swelling, loss of mobility, re-hospitalization, and even death in some cases. This project develops a novel device, specifically for use at home, to increase venous blood flow in low mobility users to prevent blood clot formation. This project improves patient outcomes and reduces the estimated $10 B in associated costs. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project leverages molecular studies that identified a key genetic pathway that regulates blood clot formation in veins. This protective pathway is activated by specific patterns of venous blood flow stimulated by typical activity and mobility. However, in individuals with low mobility this pathway can be lost resulting in an increased risk for venous blood clot formation. Because stimulation of this pathway offers powerful protection against clot formation, this project proposes a novel device specifically designed to recreate the patterns of venous flow that activate the protective genetic pathway. This pattern may be successfully created in immobile individuals with external compressions applied to the user’s calf. This project will focus on optimizing the device size and weight while maximizing patient comfort and ease of use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to develop a portable intermittent vascular compression system designed to prevent venous blood clots and treat other venous conditions. Vascular compression devices have been used for decades, most commonly in hospitals, to increase venous return and prevent blood clots. Recently, several portable compression systems have been developed to allow for easier use outside of clinical settings, such as at home after a surgical procedure when the risk for blood clots remains high. We developed a novel compression technology based on using rapid and frequent short bursts of compression to stimulate pulses of venous flow that enhance blood clot prevention. This approach of using rapid cycling compression provides significantly altered venous hemodynamics compared to traditional compression devices and is based on basic science findings connecting rapid pulses of venous flow to stimulation of vascular cell gene expression patterns that contribute to reduced blood clotting. We previously developed a hospital-based version of a rapid cycling compression system that used stored pressurized air to deliver the rapid pulses of compression required for the therapy. In this project we aimed to convert that technology into a portable product that could replicate the efficacy of the rapid cycling compression technology and make it readily available for use outside of the clinic to expand access for patients.

In order to create a portable rapid cycling compression device, we had to develop a non-pneumatic compression system, iterate the prototype system design to optimize the weight and size of the system for portability, and validate the hemodynamic performance of the system. We worked with our internal engineers and external specialized engineering firms to identify various possible actuation systems and perform basic benchtop testing to evaluate different systems. After selecting an actuation system, we built several iterative prototypes that successively improved the performance, fit and function of the system and reduced the weight and cost of the components. We validated our designs based on criteria for compression speed and force, and on the overall device size and weight. We evaluated the comfort of the prototype systems and developed a battery system to allow for untethered use of the device. Finally, we built a small batch of units to evaluate the manufacturability of the design and identify additional points for improvement. We also used the small batch units to evaluate the effect of the portable device on venous blood flow compared to our hospital device and other compression systems. We found that the portable device produced venous blood flow pulses that matched our hospital system across multiple subjects. We now have a clinically validated device design that will allow us to provide a continuum of care to patients from hospital admission through post-hospital recovery with rapid cycling compression therapy that is convenient and practical for both environments. We plan to continue clinical testing of the device with the goal of having a new treatment available for patients in the coming 2-3 years.
